newsitem.title: USA: Oracle rises on better-than-expected net.
newsitem.headline: Oracle rises on better-than-expected net.

text.p: Oracle Corp shares rose Friday after the database software company reported fiscal third-quarter earnings that matched Wall Street expectations and relieved some concerns about the company's outlook in coming months.

By early afternoon, shares of Oracle, the world's second-biggest software company after Microsoft Corp., were up 4-1/8 at 40-1/4 on trading of 11.3 million shares, making it the second-most active issue on the Nasdaq.
After the market closed Thursday, Oracle, based in Redwood Shores, Calif., said profit from operations rose to $193 million, or $0.29 a share, matching analyst estimates.
More importantly, Oracle said revenue in Europe -- a weak spot for the past few quarters -- rose 28 percent in the quarter, better than analysts expected.
"Their business is going strong on all fronts," said Bruce Raabe, analyst at brokerage Collins & Co. in San Francisco. "There's still certainly lots of demand for Oracle products in Europe."
Oracle has been reshaping its European operations to adjust to weaker economic conditions there. The effort is paying off, company executives told analysts Thursday.

Oracle also said it was on track to deliver a new version of its flagship database product by June. Once the new program, Oracle8, is introduced, customers would likely buy it "fairly aggressively," Raabe said.
